physiology.mechanism: Reducing CSF pressure allows improved perfusion to marginal spinal cord territories

high_risk_required: Open Crawford Extent I-II TAAA repair
Coverage of T8-L2 segment (artery of Adamkiewicz zone)
low_risk: TEVAR with preserved subclavian and hypogastric flow

insertion_technique.catheter: 14-gauge Tuohy needle, threading catheter into subarachnoid space
contraindications: Significant spinal stenosis or previous spinal surgery

postoperative.neurologic_monitoring: Hourly lower extremity motor and sensory exam

delayed_paraplegia_rescue.recognition: New weakness/numbness after initially intact exam
intervention: Drain CSF to lower target (≤8 mmHg)
Urgent spinal MRI if available and stable

weaning_removal.method: Clamp drain for 6-12 hours, monitor for symptoms
weaning_removal.removal: Remove if stable off drain for 6-12 hours

complications.prevention: Strict adherence to drainage limits, position head of bed elevated

outcomes_evidence.efficacy: Reduces spinal cord ischemia by approximately 50%
evidence: Coselli et al. (2002): Randomized trial showing 80% relative risk reduction in neurologic deficit
Meta-analyses confirm benefit in high-risk open TAAA repair
Retrospective data support use in extensive TEVAR

prefLabel.@value: Cerebrospinal Fluid Drainage for Spinal Cord Protection

definition.@value: Neuroprotective technique involving lumbar CSF drainage to reduce CSF pressure and improve spinal cord perfusion during aortic procedures at risk for spinal cord ischemia

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Explain the physiologic rationale for CSF drainage in aortic surgery
Identify high-risk procedures warranting CSF drainage
Describe lumbar drain insertion technique and contraindications
Outline perioperative CSF drainage management protocol
Recognize and manage complications of CSF drainage
Describe the delayed paraplegia rescue protocol
clinical_pearls: SCPP = MAP - CSF pressure: optimize both variables for best spinal protection
Limit drainage to ≤20 mL/hr and ≤250 mL/24 hours to prevent subdural hematoma
Delayed paraplegia (12-48 hours postop) often responds to aggressive rescue protocol
Prior infrarenal AAA repair is a risk factor - collaterals already sacrificed
CSF drainage reduces paraplegia risk by ~50% but does not eliminate it
